IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: SFU's mission is to advance knowledge through teaching researching and engagement with the community. We are an open inclusive university whose foundation is intellectual and academic freedom. Our scholarship unites teaching and research; we celebrate discovery diversity and dialogue. Our students and communities can expect teaching that is personal and learning opportunities that are lifelong. We champion the liberal arts and sciences and pioneering interdisciplinary and professional programs. We are a university where risks can be taken and hold initiatives embraced. Upon these foundations we will engage all our communities in building a robust and ethical society.
IRS990.MissionDesc: SFU's mission is to advance knowledge through teaching research and engagement with the community. We are an open inclusive university whose foundation is intellectual and academic freedom. Our scholarship unites teaching and research: we celebrate discovery diversity and dialogue. Our students and communities can expect teaching that is personal and learning opportunities that are lifelong. We champion the liberal arts and sciences and pioneering interdisciplinary and professional programs. We are a university where risks can be taken and bold initiatives embraced. Upon these foundations we will engage all our communities in building a robust and ethical society.
IRS990.Desc: Post Secondary Education Teaching: Delivery of Academic courses to students enrolled in Undergraduate Master and Doctorate programs as well as distance education and non-credit courses offered through Life-Long Learning. Number of students enrolled in our fiscal year April 1 2022 through March 31 2023 29,447 Undergraduates; 5,544 Graduates; including 8,164 International Students in total. Degrees awarded in the 2022 calendar year: 5,130 Bachelor; 1,088 Master; 161 PHD; 1,035 Other Grad Certificates and Diplomas

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: Research: At SFU Research Matters it's an essential component of SFU's mission and also a major instructional activity as faculty work closely with graduate and undergraduate students in a wide variety of research settings including the Library laboratories computer facilities and studios. Research collaborations extend far beyond our campuses to include many projects conducted jointly with business and industry community organizations and agencies in all levels of government. SFU researchers are establishing or strengthening programs in areas facing the most pressing social demand including international studies urban growth management public policy analysis and health sciences.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: Ancillary Services: The University provides goods and services with a student and community focus. Examples of such services include: student residences bookstore printing parking food meetings and events. In 2021 2022 these services were delivered internally alone to 29,660 Undergrad students 5,734 Grad students 4,137 full time faculty & staff and 2,504 part time faculty & staff.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The University has archaeological artefacts paintings sculptures rare books and miscellaneous items exhibited at the Art Galleries & other locations on campus. The collection is widely accessible to students in archaeology history art history and visual arts. Upon adopting Financial Reporting Framework FRF Accounting Standards March 31 2013 these assets were removed from the University's Balance Sheet.
Endowment consists of restricted donations to the university. The investment income generated from endowments must be used in accordance with purposes established by donors.

AccountActivitiesOutsideUSGrp.SpecificServicesProvidedTxt: Canadian University - FRF Financial Reporting Framework under the Canadian Public Section Accounting Standards PSAS

GrantsToOrgOutsideUSGrp.PurposeOfGrantTxt: Research - grants are made mostly to other Canadian universities for research purposes.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Activities outside of the U.S. are conducted almost entirely within Canada. Grant managers within the University's faculties & centers are responsible for administration of their budget and ensure that each grant is used for their intended purpose. Both internal and external audits are continually conducted to maintain control over the use of grant funds and their compliance with internal and external policies.
| Name :, Title:, Item Selected:, Description:| Joy Johnson, President of the University - Housing allowance personal services: the president receives use of a residence with housekeeping services.|

The Board of Governors is the senior governing body at Simon Fraser University constituted under the University Act. SFU operates under a bicameral governance system with two governing bodies: Senate and the Board of Governors. The Board is responsible for the business of the university including property revenue and policies as well as holding the President accountable. SFU's Senate is responsible for the academic governance of the university. The SFU Board of Governors has 15 members including the Chancellor the President two elected faculty members two elected students one elected staff member and eight individuals appointed by the Government of British Columbia. Board members do not receive any remuneration for their services to the Board.
Once the form 990 has been completed the report is reviewed by the Associate Director Financial Services and Director Financial Services prior to submitting to the Internal Revenue Services.
Once the form 990 has been completed the report is reviewed by the Associate Director Financial Services and Director Financial Services prior to submitting to the Internal Revenue Services.

The University's governing documents minutes of the Board policies including conflict of interest procedures and financial statements are available on its website: www.sfu.ca. SFU policies & procedures regarding conflict of interest are monitored by the University's Research Ethics Committee for all research related and non-research related disclosure. The committee issues an annual report on conflict of interest disclosures and decisions with copies also provided to the Canadian Federal Government agencies and to the University Board of Governors.

Compensation to university executives fall under the review of the Public Sector Employer's Council whose mandate falls under the Province of British Columbia. An annual report is filed with the Provincial Government available on the world wide web. The University's Board of Governors approves salary scales and compensation to key personnel.

The University's governing documents minutes of the Board policies including conflict of interest procedures and financial statements are available on it's website: www.sfu.ca Accounting method - The Financial Reporting Framework FRF is in accordance with the Budget Transparency and Accountability Act of the Province of British Columbia and the Restricted Contribution Regulation 198 2011 issued pursuant to it. The regulations require the consolidated financial statements to be prepared in accordance with Canadian Public Section Accounting Standards except that the contributions received or receivable by the university for the purpose of acquisition of tangible capital assets are accounted for as deferred capital contributions as described in note 20cv of he consolidated financial statements. The consolidated financial statements present the financial position of the university as at March 31 2023 and the results of its operations changes in net financial assets. re-measurement gains and losses and its cash flow for the year then ended.

Accounting Method - other: The Financial Reporting Framework FRF is in accordance with the Budget Transparency and Accountability Act of the Province of British Columbia and the Restricted Contribution Regulation 198 2011 issued pursuant to it. The regulations require the financial statements to be prepared in accordance with Canadian Public Sector Accounting Standards PSAS issued by the Canadian Public Sector Accounting Board except that the contributions received or receivable by the University for purpose of acquisition of tangible capital assets are accounted as deferred capital contributions as described in notes 2a and17 of the University's financial statements. For additional details the University's financial statements can be found on the world wide web - http: www.sfu ca finance publications.html
